name: Education is Priority
title: Top Education Investment
description: In 2021, Costa Rica allocated 31.17% of its government expenditure to education, showcasing a strong commitment to educational development.

name: Market Competition Champions
title: Leading in Market Competition
description: Costa Rica scored 68.55 in overall market competition and 69.81 in implementing key services promoting market competition in 2024, reflecting a robust competitive environment.

name: Unemployment Safety Net
title: Moderate Unemployment Coverage
description: In 2022, unemployment benefits and active labor market programs covered 19.02% of the population, with varying coverage across income quintiles.

name: Child Labor Concerns
title: High Child Employment in Services
description: In 2016, 53.5% of economically active children aged 7-14 were employed in services, with a significant gender disparity: 79.84% female and 45.5% male.

name: Child Workload Worries
title: Long Working Hours for Children
description: Female children aged 7-14 working only had an average workweek of 44.16 hours in 2016, indicating a high workload for young workers.

name: Youth Wage Workers
title: Significant Child Wage Employment
description: In 2016, 27.88% of children aged 7-14 in employment were wage workers, with 45.4% of female children in employment working for wages.

name: UN Aid Deficit
title: Negative Net Official Flows from UN Agencies
description: In 2021, Costa Rica experienced a negative net official flow from UN agencies, specifically UNWOMEN, amounting to -$1,366. This indicates a financial outflow rather than support from these agencies.

name: Child Labor in Agriculture
title: High Child Employment in Agriculture
description: In 2016, 36.6% of economically active children aged 7-14 in Costa Rica were employed in agriculture, with 20.16% being female. This highlights a significant reliance on child labor in the agricultural sector.

name: Family Helpers
title: High Rate of Unpaid Family Workers Among Female Children
description: In 2016, 54.59% of female children aged 7-14 in employment were unpaid family workers, indicating a high level of unpaid labor among young girls in Costa Rica.

name: Boys in School
title: Low Child Employment Among Male Children
description: In 2016, only 1.94% of male children aged 7-14 were employed, suggesting that male children are less involved in labor activities compared to their female counterparts.
